Deep in the Amazon Rainforest.

Walk into any direction, and you’ll encounter
nothing but jungle for at least 500 miles.
Here, a man is making a movie.
His name is Werner Herzog.

The footage you’re watching is from 
Burden of Dreams,

a documentary recounting the turbulent 
production of Fitzcarraldo;
which tells the story of a man determined to transport an enormous riverboat over a small mountain

in order to finance his dream of building an 
opera house in the Amazon.

Besides the obstacles you’ll find on any
production, filming so far away from civilization

also confronted Herzog and his team with injuries
and illnesses, hostile natives,
and the aggressiveness of nature itself,
which seemed intent on crushing the dreams of any man who entered its realm.
But despite these hardships, Herzog persisted,

and finished his film roughly 5 years after 
pre-production began.

It is one of the most remarkable stories in
the history of filmmaking, and yet,
for someone with a career as long and prolific as Herzog; it is but one of many exceptional tales.

His cinematic adventures have led him across
the globe more than once.

So far, he is the only director to have made
a film on every single continent.

His unique approach to filmmaking has not
gone without controversy.

Here is a man who hypnotized his entire cast
for his film Heart of Glass;
who filmed his first feature films on a stolen camera, believing firmly he had a natural right to it;

who runs a rogue film school where he teaches students
how to pick locks and forge documents;

who made five feature films with Klaus Kinski,
an actor who was notoriously difficult to work with;
who filmed volcanoes on the verge of eruption;
who once got shot during an interview by what was most likely an airsoft rifle,
and shook it off like it was nothing.
It is not significant.

It is because of the many wild stories 
such as these,
that Herzog has inadvertently built somewhat of a personal mythology around himself.

But what I am more interested in, 
is his work itself.

After all, his films are the reason famous
director François Truffaut once called Herzog
'the most important film director alive',
to which acclaimed film critic Roger Ebert adds that ‘even his failures are spectacular’.

Having watched over 40 of his films, 
I’m inclined to agree.
There is an almost spiritual quality to his stories;
and his images are filled with a beauty and absurdity

that never fail to invoke a strange, yet intimate 
sense of humanity.

So today, let’s review the work of 
this enigmatic storyteller,
examine the philosophy beneath his seemingly unwavering resolve to capture humanity on celluloid,
and explore the significance of the many stories he brought home from faraway lands.
I. THE WORKS OF WERNER HERZOG
“My films come to me very much alive, like dreams without logical patterns or academic explanations.”

Let’s start off with a basic question; 
what are Werner Herzog’s films about?

While Herzog has stated he doesn’t consciously
consider the themes in his films,

and despite his insistence that film is not the art of
scholars, but of illiterates,

I think we can nevertheless draw some 
illuminating connections.
Journeying through Herzog’s filmography,

there seems to be one fundamental conflict 
at the heart of his stories;
they are all about the human spirit as it struggles against a universe that is inherently violent and indifferent.
There is no harmony in the universe.

We have to get acquainted to this idea that
there’s no real harmony as we have conceived it.

We already find such a story in Herzog’s
first feature film.

Signs of Life was released in 1968 and tells
the story of Stroszek,

a soldier who is recovering from an injury on 
an island in Greece.

Here, we briefly see Herzog himself as one
of the extras moving Stroszek out of the truck.

The premise is simple but clever; Herzog centers
the film around a soldier;
a type of character who is generally defined by a mission that needs to be accomplished,

and puts him in a place that doesn’t offer 
any real purpose or meaning.

It doesn’t take long for boredom to set in, 
and soon,
we are following Stroszek and his fellow soldiers

as they are finding increasingly strange ways 
to occupy their minds.

Eventually, the quietness of the island drives
Stroszek insane
and he threatens to blow up an ammunition depot.

His rebellion, however, doesn’t make much
of an impact and is resolved rather quickly.

The story then ends with the island returning
to its daily business,
seemingly unaware and uncaring of the great inner turmoil experienced by this one man.

This contrast is further emphasized in Herzog’s
second feature film.

Even Dwarfs Started Small is about 
a group of dwarfs

who begin a riot against the oppressive order 
of their correctional institution.

By assuming the perspective of people who
are only about two feet tall,

the entire world around it 
becomes out of proportion.

It was Herzog’s way of highlighting that,
in his words,
it is not the dwarfs who are monstrous,

it is us and the society 
we have created for ourselves.

And it is within this absurdity, that we as
individuals struggle to assert our identities,

to make ourselves understood and establish
meaningful connections.

“It is as if there is something of an essence
or a concentrated form of each of us

that is screaming to get out and that is a perfectly
formed representation of who we are.”

Nowhere in Herzog’s filmography becomes
this longing more clear

than in his 1971 documentary film 
Land of Silence and Darkness,

which follows the both deaf and blind 
Fini Straubinger

and her work of helping others like herself who
experience the world in unimaginable isolation,
I am deaf and blind, just like you.

some of whom, like these children who were
deaf and blind from birth,
have never experienced real human contact.

The inability to communicate is also a prominent
theme in The Enigma of Kasper Hauser,
which is loosely based on the true story of Kasper Hauser who, in 1828, appeared in Nuremberg

after having been held captive in a locked
room since as long as he could remember.

of who Kaspar was,

where he came from and who imprisoned

Herzog was more interested in Kaspar himself.
Having no concept of the world,
Herzog saw him as someone who was completely isolated from society;

This fundamental struggle is present in virtually
every film Herzog has made.

It’s there in his fictional films; like Woyzeck,

Hi, how are you?

Herzog even went as far as saying all his
characters belong to the same family,

They have no shadows, they are without pasts,

I have always thought of my films as really being one big work that I have been concentrating on for forty years.

The characters in this huge story are all 
desperate and solitary rebels
with no language with which to communicate.
Inevitably, they suffer because of this.
They know their rebellion is doomed to failure,
but they continue without respite,
wounded, struggling on their own without assistance.”

Herzog’s characters all remind us of our
own desire to express ourselves,

to make clear to others who we are, and how often 
we stumble and fall in that effort,

how often we experience a 
deep sense of loneliness
when we are unable to articulate our thoughts and dreams to those around us.

“What they understand as ambition, hope,
or happiness, will always be a mystery to us.”

And so, those people on the furthest 
fringes of our societies,
those who have been cast out, misunderstood, or been faced with incredible trauma,

do not become outsiders in 
the films of Werner Herzog.
Instead, they become saints;
embodiments of the human spirit that exists within each and every one of us, longing to manifest itself.
II. IN SEARCH FOR ADEQUATE IMAGES

As a remedy to our inability to articulate ourselves, 
our loneliness,
Herzog often speaks of our need for adequate images;
We need pure and absolute images to reflect our civilization as whole

and our own deep
inner voices.

From here, we can turn our attention from
the stories, to the storyteller.

Herzog laments the worn out images that surround
us in our modern civilization,

the posters and postcards, the Hollywood sets, 
and of course; the television.

If you switch on television it’s just ridiculous

In this brief documentary called

The  real point of the story however wasn’t that Herzog had no faith in his fellow filmmaker,

but rather that he wanted to motivate Morris

which in this case became the acclaimed documentary

But more importantly; the short film reflects

These images can be man-made, for example;

It is exactly through filming in the real
world

that is not found with other filmmakers.

This becomes especially clear

Take a film like Fitzcarraldo for example;

sets, props and scale models,
but not with Herzog who believes that the audience intuitively knows what is real,
and that it affects how they watch the film.

And you can tell the difference, that this
is not a plastic boat, and that this,

Much of what you see in Herzog’s films is

He really used hundreds of rats in Nosferatu,

Invincible.

And these actors really lost weight to portray

This commitment to bring reality into his fictional films has led to some unorthodox directorial decisions.

For The Enigma of Kasper Hauser, Herzog cast
a man named Bruno to play Kasper,

a choice which seems rather odd seeing 
as Bruno was an adult

and Kasper was still a young boy 
when he was found.
Bruno however, had a troubled past of his own;

as a child, he was beaten so badly by his mother 
that he lost his speech
and he ended up spending the majority of his life in asylums, prisons and foster homes.
And it was this vulnerability that convinced Herzog that Bruno would capture the essence of Kasper
better than any actor could have done.

As mentioned before, Herzog experimented with
hypnosis in Heart of Glass.
The film is about a prophet who foresees an apocalyptic event and the town that declares him mad.

Herzog’s vision was one of collective madness,
of characters who are aware of a coming catastrophe
and yet continue to walk straight into it.

It is this deliriousness that Herzog makes
visceral to the audience through hypnosis,

which put everyone except the prophet into 
a walking daze, turned their hearts into glass.
The hypnosis therefore, was not a tool of manipulation, but one of stylization,
a way to emphasize the underlying story.
The main point is that all of these images emit a realness that contains a self-transcendent quality,

and these are precisely the kind of images 
Herzog is looking for,

those that tell a greater story 
and resonate with us on a deeper level.

Give us adequate images, we lack adequate images, 
our civilization doesn’t have adequate images,

and I think a civilization is doomed
or is gonna die out like dinosaurs

if it does not develop an adequate language 
or adequate images.
I see it as a very, very dramatic situation,

and that’s what I’m working on; 
a new grammar of images.
III. CINEMATIC REALITIES

While there is indeed a significant amount
of reality in Herzog’s fictional films,

he seems to take the opposite approach 
with his non-fictional films.

Those who have seen films like Fata Morgana
or Lessons of Darkness know the footage isn’t

presented as it is in a literal sense; 
it is curated and fictionalized;
the desert landscapes of Fata Morgana are accompanied by music
and a retelling of the Mayan creation myth.

And the burning oil fields in Lessons of Darkness
are turned into something

which feels more like an apocalyptic 
science fiction film.
Something is looming over this city, this city that will soon be laid waste by war.
Now it is still alive, biding its time.
Nobody has yet begun to suspect the impeding doom.

This stylization serves to reveal 
a deeper truth,

to capture something essential 
about the human experience.

And this brings us to the question of the
nature of our reality and how cinema represents it.

And because Herzog’s thoughts on the subject
are rather unconventional,

we must make a brief detour to get the 
necessary historical context.

In the early 60’s, the question of how to
capture and represent reality resulted in

two comparable yet distinct methods 
for filming documentaries;

the first being Direct Cinema, 
which originated in the United States and Canada,

and the second being Cinema Vérité, 
which was developed in France.
This film was made without actors,
but lived by men and women who devoted some of their time to a novel experiment of 'cinéma vérité.'

Both were characterized by a search for 
a new cinematic truth,

the main goal being to create more objective and 
honest representations of reality,

and were made possible by the 
development of lightweight camera’s
and portable, synchronized sound recorders, which allowed for more non-intrusive ways of filming.

This quest for objective realism posed a significant
methodological problem

as the act of filmmaking is by its very nature 
a manipulation of reality,
and can therefore never achieve a true reflection of it.

To account for this, Direct Cinema argued
that the filmmaker should be a passive observer,

a fly on the wall as it were, and strive to
capture the world as objectively as possible,

and represent it in such a way that it feels
as if reality is unfolding naturally before the audience.

Cinema Vérité has a slightly different philosophy
about the role of the filmmaker
and suggests more active participation

in which the filmmaker is included into the film 
as a subjective observer,

thereby making the process of filmmaking
more transparent
and giving the audience more insight into the relation between the observer and the observed.

This method also allows for more staging and
interventions, which, according to Dan Kraus,

a well-known filmmaker in 
the Cinema Vérité tradition,

doesn’t contradict the goal of 
capturing truthful realities.

He states that;
“No documentary can ever show you the truth,
because there are multiple truths,

but vérité can at least relay the truth as seen 
by a single observer.”
While Cinema Vérité has been criticized for at times feeling more like reporting than artistic expression,
it has nevertheless become an influential method that, together with Direct Cinema,

is still popular today in both non-fictional, 
as well as fictional filmmaking.

Herzog however, fundamentally disagrees 
with this philosophy,
and has a wholly different approach when it comes to capturing cinematic truth,

Indeed, as well known as Herzog is for bringing

In Encounters at the End of the World

Scenes such as these may not be factually
